titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: Horsley from Hartlepool came to see me, and stayed to lunch. He is a successful merchant, very anxious not to fall under the temptations incident to money–making, and eager to do good in such ways as are open to him. He has a great admiration for A. L. Smith, whose influence is evidently strong on him. I went into the Great Library to walk, as the weather is still cold & raw, &, while I was there, a party of wounded soldiers were brought in by the verger. I took charge of them, & shewed them over the Deanery.
Bishop Jewell was hardly a believer in Apostolical succession: "
God's grace is promised to a good mind, & to any one that feareth Him, not unto sees and successions
." I wish the English Bishops spoke in that way now.
